title: The collapse of Woodford is having a chilling effect on funding for UK science and technology
text:
When Neil Woodford invested in Metalysis, a Cambridge University spinout company, in 2016, he was billed by its executives as “one of Britain’s most prominent fund managers”.

The 3D printer company said Woodford was an “outstanding strategic partner” who was excited by the firm’s disruptive technology and “would offer them “fantastic support”.

But things changed earlier this year. Woodford, it turned out, was “no longer in a position to invest” – neither were its other investors for that matter – and its debts were spiralling.

After a year-long scramble for cash, Metalysis eventually collapsed into administration. Just a month later, Malta-registered Power Resources Group swooped on the business...
